name: LASER 2001
keyboard: QWERTY, 49 typewriter keysCTRL, 2 SHIFT and large SPACE BAR
sound: 4 voices (3 voice channels + 1 noise channel)from 245 to 12500 Hz
ports: expansion port (system bus), audio output, composite video output, RF TV video output, cassette interface, 2 x joystick ports (Atari standard DB9), cartridge slot
power: External PSU (see exact specs in the MORE PICTURES section)
description:
In June 1983, Video Technology presented a prototype of the Laser 2001 (and the Apple II compatible Laser 3000 the same day) which can use Colecovision and Atari VCS 2600 cartridges!

The Laser 2001 was also sold as the Salora Manager in Scandinavia

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future....  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"9990 francs the TO9. Colors included" <br><br> "Thomson. All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Sinclair spirit is in him''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It has not finished to surprise you"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #5 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">If you could talk to Thomas Edison, he'd tell you what it was like to turn the light on in 1879. You could tell him about some bright idea of the 20th century... particularly, a technological phenomenon that can handle everything from solar heat control to lighting you home via voice command. The Apple personal computer...<br> ... With Apple, Edison could've written a program to determine why some filaments burned longer than others...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote>... featuring the Intellivoice</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HP BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Extract of an HP sales brochure describing the models of the HP 9000-200 series.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> CORTEX has been designed not to dominate your desk, to leave room for your calendar, your telephone, your in-tray and the rest. If you want it inconspicuous, buy iy in conventional cream. But for extroverts, and the fashion conscious, CORTEX comes in bright, bright colours - warm red, C/WP green, sunshine yellow, ice white and all black...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PASOPIA 16 JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris"><a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a part of a complete French price list of the C64 and VIC-20, including peripherals, accessories and software.<br> You can download the <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Commodore/FrPriceList.zip">complete version</a>.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/">ITSR'S NES ARCHIVE</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTERS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICRO7 COVERPAGE (SEPT. 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Micro7 was a french computing magazine in the 80's. In september 84, its first page was featuring the EXl-100.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>“Why be content with a video game system?<br> Today, the VIC-20 is available at a special price.”<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br> No waiting for software<font color="#666666"> ...This exciting micro has fired the imagination of programmers who are busy developping new software to take full advantage of its performance capabilities...</font><br><br> No wait state<font color="#666666"> ...One advantage is the total elimination of memory access wait states so that interaction between the processor, RAM and disk drive is speeded up...</font><br><br> A free p-System for those who don't wait <font color="#666666"> ...A free p-System operating system and PASCAL, FORTRAN 77 and BASIC compilers which alone lists for $1475, we're now including free with the Sage II...</font>  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #11</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

hardwareDescription:
Here are the known extensions for the Laser 2001 :

- 128k 5"1/4 Disk drive
- Printer Cable
- 16k RAM memory expansion 
- Joysticks
- Colecovision expansion module
- Backup expansion card
